content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle, the statement is clear and there is lots of tests/validators to cover all the possible cases.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The statement is clear and the test cases are plenty.

It is quite straightforward so I have nothing to say other than I enjoyed it.

Minor caveats:
* (At Output) n Lines: each line is number of possible arrangements of corresponding case
> Seems to be lacking a word
* Change pattern to [[pattern]] in the statement.
* (Unless it was intended) You don't need an extra space after:

`{{.#...#....###.}}
{{..#..#....###.}}
{{.#....#...###.}}
{{..#...#...###.}}`

It automatically adds one, so adding one space results in having two spaces after the example.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
This puzzle is related to the paper-and-pencil puzzle nonogram.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: ☑ Neat memoization exercise.
☑ Clear statement.
☑ Extensive test cases.
☑ No snakes were hurt in the making of this puzzle.

If you add that snakes with length > 1 have 2 possible orientations, solution becomes solution bit-shifted by number of snakes with length > 1.

Does a snake of length 1 have a tail ?

Input
* Please change '[[snake list (separated by ",")]]' to:

[[snake list]] (comma-separated integers representing the lengths of the snakes)

Output
* Please change "[[n]] lines," to "<<[[n]] Lines>>:".

Thanks.
